content: The Act may be cited as the "Althea Gibson Excellence Act." Althea Gibson, born in 1927 in South Carolina, faced racism and segregation in tennis despite her talent. She excelled in all-Black tournaments but was denied entry into major events due to her skin color. Gibson graduated from Florida A & M University and worked as an athletic instructor. The "Althea Gibson Excellence Act" honors her legacy. Althea Gibson, a trailblazing African-American tennis player, broke the color barrier in the 1950s by winning championships at major tournaments like the French Open, US Open, Australian Doubles, and Wimbledon. She was the first African-American player to be allowed to enter the Forest Hills Championship in 1950. Gibson's exceptional grass play at the Eastern Grass Court Championships led to a policy reevaluation by the USLTA, earning her a bid to Forest Hills. Althea Gibson's tennis career flourished despite discrimination. She was the first African-American invited to Wimbledon in 1951 and went on to win the women's singles and doubles in 1957 and 1958. Gibson also became the first African-American woman to win the French Open in 1956. Throughout her career, she won 56 doubles and singles titles, gaining national and international acclaim. In the late 1950s, she won eleven major titles, including three consecutive doubles at the French Open and the U.S. Open. Althea was named Female Athlete of the Year by the Associated Press in 1957. Althea Gibson was named Female Athlete of the Year by the Associated Press in 1957 and again in 1958. She turned professional at 31 after winning her second U.S. Championship. Gibson later became a professional golfer and the first African-American woman to join the LGPA. After retiring from golf, she focused on public service, serving as the New Jersey Commissioner of Athletics and on various boards. Gibson was inducted into a prestigious organization. Althea Gibson was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in 1971 and the International Women's Sports Hall of Fame in 1980. She received the Theodore Roosevelt Award from the NCAA in 1991, becoming the first woman to receive this honor. Gibson passed away in 2003 in East Orange, NJ. Her legacy continues to inspire youth and pave the way for other African-American tennis players like Arthur Ashe. Joining the ranks of distinguished Congressional Gold Medal recipients would be a fitting accolade for Althea Gibson's achievements. Althea Gibson will be posthumously awarded a Congressional Gold Medal for her groundbreaking achievements in athletics and her efforts to combat racial discrimination. The medal will be presented by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate, with the design to be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be created. The Secretary has the authority to create duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal, sell them at a price to cover costs, and designate them as national medals. All medals struck under this Act are considered numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale of these medals can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the costs of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
